IDE Setup

Configure your editor for the best PhilJS development experience with syntax highlighting, IntelliSense, and debugging.

Visual Studio Code

VS Code is the recommended editor for PhilJS development. Install the official extension for the best experience.

Install the PhilJS Extension

Terminal
$code --install-extension philjs.philjs-vscode

Or search for "PhilJS" in the VS Code Extensions marketplace.

Features

  • JSX/TSX syntax highlighting optimized for PhilJS
  • IntelliSense for signal APIs
  • Snippets for common patterns
  • Go to definition for components
  • Error diagnostics from the PhilJS compiler
  • Integrated debugging

Recommended Settings

Add these to your .vscode/settings.json:

.vscode/settings.jsonjson
1{
2  // Enable TypeScript in JSX files
3  "typescript.tsdk": "node_modules/typescript/lib",
4  "typescript.enablePromptUseWorkspaceTsdk": true,
5 
6  // Format on save
7  "editor.formatOnSave": true,
8  "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode",
9 
10  // File associations
11  "files.associations": {
12    "*.tsx": "typescriptreact"
13  },
14 
15  // Emmet for JSX
16  "emmet.includeLanguages": {
17    "typescriptreact": "html"
18  },
19 
20  // PhilJS specific
21  "philjs.enableSignalTracking": true,
22  "philjs.showInlineHints": true
23}

Recommended Extensions

.vscode/extensions.jsonjson
1{
2  "recommendations": [
3    "philjs.philjs-vscode",
4    "esbenp.prettier-vscode",
5    "dbaeumer.vscode-eslint",
6    "bradlc.vscode-tailwindcss",
7    "formulahendry.auto-rename-tag",
8    "christian-kohler.path-intellisense"
9  ]
10}

Debug Configuration

.vscode/launch.jsonjson
1{
2  "version": "0.2.0",
3  "configurations": [
4    {
5      "name": "PhilJS: Chrome",
6      "type": "chrome",
7      "request": "launch",
8      "url": "http://localhost:5173",
9      "webRoot": "${workspaceFolder}/src",
10      "sourceMaps": true,
11      "sourceMapPathOverrides": {
12        "webpack:///src/*": "${webRoot}/*"
13      }
14    },
15    {
16      "name": "PhilJS: Server",
17      "type": "node",
18      "request": "launch",
19      "runtimeExecutable": "npm",
20      "runtimeArgs": ["run", "dev"],
21      "skipFiles": ["<node_internals>/**"],
22      "console": "integratedTerminal"
23    }
24  ]
25}

WebStorm / IntelliJ IDEA

JetBrains IDEs have excellent TypeScript support out of the box.

Install the Plugin

  1. Open Settings/Preferences
  2. Go to Plugins > Marketplace
  3. Search for "PhilJS"
  4. Install and restart

Configure TypeScript

  1. Open Settings/Preferences
  2. Go to Languages & Frameworks > TypeScript
  3. Set TypeScript to use the project's version
  4. Enable "Use TypeScript Service" for code completion

Neovim

For Neovim users, we recommend using nvim-lspconfig with TypeScript LSP.

Required Plugins

lua/plugins/lsp.lualua
1-- Using lazy.nvim
2return {
3  -- LSP
4  {
5    "neovim/nvim-lspconfig",
6    dependencies = {
7      "williamboman/mason.nvim",
8      "williamboman/mason-lspconfig.nvim",
9    },
10    config = function()
11      require("lspconfig").tsserver.setup({
12        -- PhilJS JSX settings
13        init_options = {
14          preferences = {
15            jsxAttributeCompletionStyle = "auto",
16          },
17        },
18        settings = {
19          typescript = {
20            inlayHints = {
21              includeInlayParameterNameHints = "all",
22              includeInlayFunctionParameterTypeHints = true,
23            },
24          },
25        },
26      })
27    end,
28  },
29 
30  -- Treesitter for syntax highlighting
31  {
32    "nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter",
33    build = ":TSUpdate",
34    config = function()
35      require("nvim-treesitter.configs").setup({
36        ensure_installed = { "tsx", "typescript", "javascript", "html", "css" },
37        highlight = { enable = true },
38      })
39    end,
40  },
41 
42  -- Auto pairs for JSX
43  {
44    "windwp/nvim-ts-autotag",
45    config = function()
46      require("nvim-ts-autotag").setup()
47    end,
48  },
49}

Rust IDE Setup

For Rust development with PhilJS, additional setup is needed.

VS Code with rust-analyzer

Terminal
$code --install-extension rust-lang.rust-analyzer

Add to your .vscode/settings.json:

.vscode/settings.jsonjson
1{
2  "rust-analyzer.procMacro.enable": true,
3  "rust-analyzer.cargo.features": "all",
4  "rust-analyzer.diagnostics.disabled": [
5    "unresolved-proc-macro"
6  ],
7  "rust-analyzer.checkOnSave.command": "clippy",
8  "[rust]": {
9    "editor.formatOnSave": true,
10    "editor.defaultFormatter": "rust-lang.rust-analyzer"
11  }
12}

RustRover / CLion

JetBrains Rust IDEs work out of the box. Enable the proc-macro support in settings for the view! macro.

Code Snippets

The PhilJS extension includes these snippets:

PrefixDescription
pfcPhilJS Function Component
psigCreate a signal
pmemoCreate a memo
peffCreate an effect
presCreate a resource
pctxCreate a context

Custom Snippets

Add custom snippets to .vscode/philjs.code-snippets:

.vscode/philjs.code-snippetsjson
1{
2  "PhilJS Component": {
3    "prefix": "pfc",
4    "body": [
5      "import { signal } from 'philjs-core';",
6      "",
7      "interface ${1:$TM_FILENAME_BASE}Props {",
8      "  $2",
9      "}",
10      "",
11      "export function ${1:$TM_FILENAME_BASE}({ $3 }: ${1:$TM_FILENAME_BASE}Props) {",
12      "  $0",
13      "  return (",
14      "    <div>",
15      "      ",
16      "    </div>",
17      "  );",
18      "}"
19    ],
20    "description": "Create a PhilJS component"
21  },
22  "Signal": {
23    "prefix": "psig",
24    "body": ["const $1 = signal<$2>($3);"],
25    "description": "Create a signal"
26  },
27  "Effect": {
28    "prefix": "peff",
29    "body": [
30      "effect(() => {",
31      "  $1",
32      "  return () => {",
33      "    $2",
34      "  };",
35      "});"
36    ],
37    "description": "Create an effect with cleanup"
38  }
39}
